VMarcoV, you fool there is a list of what works on the torrent description, your bullshit thing is not required, anyone that can read knows what will and will not work, thanks for your efforts but you are just confusing yourself.

Intel 3945, 4965, 5100, 5150, 5300, and 5350 Adapters 

Supported only under Windows Vista, Windows 2008, and Windows 7. 

Make sure that the Intel driver that you are using for your adapter is version 12.4.3.9 or higher. Older driver versions will not work properly in monitor mode. If you're using an older driver version, please visit www.intel.com to download the latest version. 
Packet injection using Packet Generator is not possible. 
When monitoring 802.11n networks with 40 MHz channel bonding, you cannot choose whether the secondary 20 MHz channel is below or above the primary one; the adapter's default settings will be used. Note that Intel's 3945 and 4965 adapters don't support 40 MHz channels in the 2.4 GHz band; whereas Intel's 5100, 5150, 5300, and 5350 models support 40 MHz channels in the 2.4 GHz band as long as the corresponding setting is enabled in the driver properties in Device Manager. 
When monitoring 802.11n networks, the adapter driver reports the packet transmission rate of 802.11n packets incorrectly. For example, a packet with a rate of 270 Mbps might appear with a rate of 1 Mbps or 9 Mbps. This is an issue with the adapter driver that is out of our control.

Not everyone know which adapter they have. My upload saves them the effort of finding out. AND the effort of checking with the lists. 

The reason why Intel's card doesn't work is because it doesn't support injection.

Hello,

I'm having trouble making this work, I have a Dell Wireless 1505 draft 802.11n WLAN Mini-Card Rev 2.0. The list says this is supported, and after forcing an update of CommView it installed the appropriate driver. I began generating packets, however nothing ever appeared in the protocol column. The other computer I was using never got limited access notification, it returned an invalid network key message instead. So I kept entering random passwords and submitting them which made my packet traffic increase each time. When I finally got past 20,000 packets I tried to save the packets, but it said there were no packets there. Even though it clearly said there were 20,000+ at the little diagnostics bar at the very bottom. I'm not sure what is up, or what I did wrong. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Cheers,
Stiel
